content.description:
One of South Platte’s gems; a unique, crimpy, arete and dihedral feature. This line offers thoughtful movement and consistency, and sending always seems to give people much more trouble than expected.

From an awkward sit start off the unfortunate landing, with hands matched on an undercling/sidepull hold, pull on and move to a slippery rail. Techy crimping on the arete sets up for a long move to an edge in the corner. Drop knees and interesting positions lead to a final throw for the glorious lip jug. Easy topout.

I have left the FA credits blank due to some controversy regarding this one. However, both of the problems’ pioneers did a great job with the vision behind the line.
content.protection: Several pads. Unfortunately the landing kind of sucks
content.location: The obvious line on the Wolf Boulder. Sds on a good hold on the faint arete, and climb up the pure line of holds of finish through the skylight.

content.description:
Paul Robinson’s low start to Wolf at the Door takes a great line and adds a slightly less awkward start, along with some difficulty.

Begin squatting at the bottom of the wall, on the flat earth, from a good sidepull edge. A huge right hand cross move leads immediately into Wolf with some extra fatigue, making a low percentage line even harder.

Personally, I think this line adds some fun moves and a better start to Wolf, but Wolf is already so great it’s hard to say if this is truly a better line. If you can, do them both. It doesn’t matter. Have fun on this southern crimp fest.
content.protection: Only one more pad then needed for Wolf.
content.location: Starts about 6 feet down and right from Wolf, on a nice sidepull, with bad feet. Climb left and into Wolf.

pathTokens: Sleeping Rock aka Sheep's Nose Bouldering
